abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Cotton Sector Reform
            Project for Benin were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, Bank performance was moderately satisfactory,
            and Borrower performance was moderately unsatisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: using investment lending in tandem
            with budget support to implement difficult reforms may be
            more effective than each instrument alone. The project under
            review experienced that reforms are extremely difficult to
            implement within a sector as strategic and as politically
            sensitive as cotton. Even if it is clearly stated initially,
            Government commitment can hardly be taken for granted on a
            long period of time, unless irreversible steps are taken at
            the beginning of the reform process, which was not the case
            in the Benin reform process. The privatization of National
            Company for agricultural production was finally completed
            under joint support of specific investment lending and
            budget support. Budget support can signal and facilitate
            commitment to reforms. Strong sector teams from the
            investment side are, however, needed to lead an effective
            policy dialogue. Institutional development and structural
            reforms should be outward looking and keep an eye on
            evolving global developments. The project under review and
            the underlying cotton sector reform were affected by
            decisions of key stakeholders driven by internal struggles
            and the political economy of the national cotton sector.
            Evidence based analysis highlighting the performance of
            alternative approaches followed in the region could have
            improved decision making. The Bank is well suited to provide
            such kind of input as shown by the recently completed
            comparative analysis of Organization and Performance of
            African Cotton Sectors (World Bank 2008). The project was
            further affected by developments on international commodity
            and financial markets. Designs need to be forward looking,
            anticipate such external effects and be flexible enough to adapt.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Cotton Sector Reform Project in
            Benin, will facilitate transition to a competitive system,
            by supporting the private sector operations, and
            institutional change resulting from the privatization of the
            National Company for Agricultural Promotion's (SONAPRA)
            ginning activities. The project components' main focus
            is on supporting the institutions involved in cotton
            ginning, and primary marketing activities, namely the
            Association Inter-professionnelle du Coton (AIC), Centrale
            de Securisation des Paiements et du Recouvrement (CSPR), and
            Federations des Unions de Producteurs (FUPRO) become
            operationally effective, and institutionally strong.
            Technical assistance, and advisory services will be
            provided, to cover management responsibilities, auditing,
            and financing operations, including training for
            institutional capacity building. Furthermore, the project
            will support the implementation of sector-wide technical
            services programs, in an effort for the private sector to
            take responsibility over the agricultural services, and
            other technical support functions carried out by SONAPRA,
            whose ginning plants, and operations' privatization,
            includes assistance, and advisory services for the reform
            process, and for addressing the social aspects, and
            financial needs of the government's conversion program.

repnme.cdata!:
Benin - Projet de Reformes du Secteur
            Cotonnier : etude d'impact environnementale

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment (EA) looks
            at the activities, and processes of cotton ginneries in
            Benin, and examines its equipment, and site location, to
            determine the associated environmental, and socioeconomic
            impacts, so as to propose mitigation measures. Following a
            review of the country's environmental regulatory
            framework, the EA points at the weak environmental
            performance of cotton ginneries, which despite environmental
            legislation, disregard the current regulatory framework.
            Pollution control measures are inefficient, conducive to
            detrimental socioeconomic consequences: vegetative
            degradation, air pollution, inefficient drainage, and
            contaminated effluents, in addition to oil spills, and noise
            disturbances. Measures to mitigate adversity call for the
            creation of an environmental management committee, to
            establish, and validate the cotton ginneries environmental
            plan of action, set in place environmental units, and
            formulate pilot pollution control programs. The cotton
            ginneries at Savalou, and Bohicon should be permanently
            closed, proposing to transform Savalou into a museum, and,
            Bohicon, into a cotton gin training school, following the
            building's restoration. Modification of chimneys,
            drainage, and canalization, as well as soundproof works, and
            appropriate effluents discharge, should be implemented at
            existing cotton ginneries, to reduce emissions, prevent
            flooding, and reduce noise disturbances from power engines.
            Capacity building, and training should be provided to
            enforce environmental measures, equipment should be
            adequately maintained, and public health surveillance ensured.
